title: LanguageChange request
body:
by **Joachim.Wuttke**: 
»An identifier is exported if both:
   1. the first character of the identifier's name is a Unicode upper case
letter (Unicode class "Lu"); and
   2. the identifier is declared in the package block or denotes a field or
method of a type declared in that block.«

In my view, after some study of critical reviews, condition (1) is the most
regrettable decision taken in the design of go. Rationale: (a) This is
quite a heavy restriction of my freedom to choose variable names that are
the most appropriate in my context & programming style; (b) it's not well
compatible with the freedom to use UTF-8: there are many scripts that don't
have a full fledged lower case / upper case distinction; (c) what if I want
to change visibility - I have to change every single occurence of the
variable. Why not use a keyword like "export" or "public" ? Little
more
typing, but huge gain in flexibility and readability.
